results.title: Permutations
results.brief_description:
An early example of computer generated animation; several hundred dots move about the screen according to a set of
instructions in a graphics program which were input into a
IBM digital computer and coloured by an optical printer.
‘Action sequences, proceeding from order to disorder and back to ordered patterning, suggest a parallel to harmonic phenomena of the musical scale … The effect is to subtly generate and resolve tension - which is similar to the primary emotional power of music composition’ (John Whitney).

results.title: Retailing
results.creator_credit: Mutual Life and Citizens' Assurance Co. and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
A vocational guidance film. Shows the wide variety of departments and discusses the varied opportunities in retailing, including advertising and art. Retailing is an exciting avenue of employment in which people are needed for a wide variety of departments, some into contact with the customers and others handling “behind-the-scenes” jobs. Shows how young people with executive ability may find opportunities in office management, buying, advertising, art and other retailing careers. (Some footage of David Jones store and an old supermarket interior).

results.title: Experiments in motion graphics
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: In this documentary film exploring his working processes, John Whitney explains some of the techniques and philosophies involved in programming and animating his computer-made abstract films. He attempts to define his new art of ‘motion graphics’ by comparison with music and language. As well as an intriguing investigation into his work, this film is a visual feast of his remarkable dynamic abstractions.
results.description: In this documentary film exploring his working processes, John Whitney explains some of the techniques and philosophies involved in programming and animating his computer-made abstract films. He attempts to define his new art of ‘motion graphics’ by comparison with music and language. As well as an intriguing investigation into his work, this film is a visual feast of his remarkable dynamic abstractions.
description_for_label: In this documentary film exploring his working processes, John Whitney explains some of the techniques and philosophies involved in programming and animating his computer-made abstract films. He attempts to define his new art of ‘motion graphics’ by comparison with music and language. As well as an intriguing investigation into his work, this film is a visual feast of his remarkable dynamic abstractions.

results.title: Radio and television technician
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
Work of the skilled radio and television technician includes the manufacture of radio and television receivers, the operation and maintenance of broadcasting equipment and telecommunications services. This is a field which is constantly expanding, and those who gain additional qualifications can progress to computer engineering, radio frequency heating and satellite communications.

results.title: Planning
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Job Catch”.
A successful job application is dependent on careful preparation and presentation of academic record, work experience and related activities. It also requires a clear understanding of the job and the reasons for applying. “Planning” presents an easy to follow guide on how to prepare job applications. It discusses the following three points : 1.Preparation of reports, references, resumes and letters; 2.Knowledge of the job; 3.How to present a clear description of one’s self to the employer.

results.title: Coping
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Job Catch”.
This is part of series designed for use by upper secondary students and school leavers. The transition from being a student to a working young adult seeking independence can be fraught with unexpected responsibilities and financial problems. This program describes what to expect once you begin working, together with hints on basic survival techniques and personal budgeting.

results.title: Performing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Job Catch”.
This film demonstrates ways in which an applicant can take a more positive role in a job interview by gaining a thorough understanding of the job interview process, thereby ensuring a more confident and relaxed attitude. Methods of utilising information on the nature of the job, and the work operations of the company or organisation are discussed, together with ways of improving performance in the job interview.

results.title: Choosing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Job Catch”.
This is part of a series designed for use by upper secondary school students and school leavers. This program shows students how to determine an appropriate career path based on their personal and creative attributes and interests. It outlines a four stage process for subject choice - self description, creating a direction, active investigation and taking action.

results.title: The World is not enough (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Featuring the longest pre credit sequence in the Bond franchise, “The World is not enough” has more than one fiendish villain and a start including a knife throwing sniper, a brief interlude, then an extended powerboat chase on the Thames followed by a hot air balloon. British oil tycoon Sir Robert King is killed via a booby trap at MI6 by a terrorist, thought to be Renard the Anarchist (Robert Carlyle) - an ex KGB agent whose only goal is to create chaos. His claim to fame is a bullet permanently lodged in his head, killing off his senses as well as any feeling of pain, effectively making him super-human. Renard was also responsible for the kidnapping of King’s daughter Elektra (Sophie Marceau) and Bond is sent to protect her and to find the traitor on staff. A ploy is uncovered to steal an atomic missile and use it for sabotage. Nuclear scientist Dr Christmas Jones (Denise Richards) assists Bond is the retrieval process, as well as providing Bond with another potential conquest. Notorious for being the last film in which Q (Desmond Llewelyn) appears, we also see a more humanised M (Judi Dench) and a dazzling array of inventive chase sequences.
